channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Berlusconi’s Brother Uses Slur for Mario Balotelli
item.description: Paolo Berlusconi’s remarks about the soccer star attracted little attention in the Italian news media, even though Italy has a growing problem with attitudes toward its expanding immigrant population.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: It was considered a coup, politically as well as athletically, when Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister, shelled out 20 million euros last month to land Mario Balotelli, the star striker, for his soccer team, A. C. Milan.

item.title: Dublin Journal: Seeking Redress in Ireland Over Magdalene Laundry
item.description: The daughters of a woman who was held in one of Ireland’s notorious Magdalene Laundries have been campaigning for an apology from the state for 10 years.
item.dc:creator: By CAROL RYAN
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Ms. Long, above, and Ms. Thornton-Verma found their birth mother in one of Ireland’s Magdalene Laundries, where she had toiled, unpaid, for decades.

item.title: English Hospital Report Cites ‘Appalling’ Suffering in Staffordshire
item.description: The report, which examined conditions at Stafford Hospital over a 50-month period between 2005 and 2009, found that many of the problems were due to the efforts of the hospital to meet health-service targets.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: Members of the media at Stafford Hospital, where, a report said, hundreds of patients died needlessly from 2005 to 2009.

item.title: At War Blog: Interview With Gen. John R. Allen on Leaving Afghanistan
item.description: The New York Times interviewed Gen. John. R. Allen on Sunday, a week before his scheduled departure from Afghanistan after 19 months as the commander of the American and allied forces.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: General Allen, Departing Afghan War Commander, Saw as Much Diplomacy as Combat
item.description: General John R. Allen is leaving a war that has become as much about damage control and crisis diplomacy as fighting the Taliban.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. John R. Allen, in his office, has been the senior American commander in Afghanistan since July 2011. His last day is Sunday.

item.title: New Skirmishes Reported in Mali as France Promises Withdrawal
item.description: France renewed a promise that its soldiers would begin returning home within weeks, just as new hostilities erupted with Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: French armored vehicles moved toward the Niger border before making a turn to the north on Wednesday in Gao, northern Mali.

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Prime Minister Criticized for Soliloquy on 'Ignorant' Mothers
item.description: In the middle of political turmoil, Egypt's prime minister, Hisham Qandil, took a moment to blame infant diarrhea on the unclean breasts of "ignorant" nursing mothers.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Women present for the Egyptian prime minister's remarks blaming "ignorant" mothers' unclean breasts for diarrhea in nursing infants appeared confused and uncomfortable.

item.title: The Lede: Video of Protests Across Tunisia After an Opposition Leader Is Gunned Down
item.description: Video and photographs shot by Tunisian activists and bloggers on Wednesday gave close-up views of protests across the country.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: Your Suggestions on Curbing Violence Against Women in India
item.description: A round-up of readers' comments received over the past week on India Ink.
item.dc:creator: By HANNA INGBER
item.media:description: Indians attend a protest against gender discrimination and sexual violence in New Delhi on Jan. 26.

item.title: Tunisia Moves to Contain Fallout After Opposition Figure Is Assassinated
item.description: The prime minister said he would dissolve the Islamist-led government after a politician, Chokri Belaid, was killed and thousands took to the streets in protest.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MONICA MARKS and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Protesters surrounded the ambulance carrying the body of Chokri Belaid, the general secretary of the secular Tunisian Democratic Patriots party, who was shot dead earlier Wednesday in Tunis.

item.title: The Lede: Online Campaign Draws Attention to Case of Saudi Father Accused of Rape and Torture
item.description: Reports that a man in Saudi Arabia, who had frequently appeared on television as a preacher, had raped and tortured to death his 5-year-old daughter have fueled outrage online.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: I.H.T. Special: Syria's Kurds Try to Balance Security and Alliances
item.description: Syria’s Kurds have mostly escaped direct conflict in the country’s civil war, but with rebel units pushing east toward the Kurdish heartland, this may not remain the case.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JOSH WOOD

item.title: Irish Premier’s Apology Fails to Appease Workhouse Survivors
item.description: A 1,o00-page government report puts a spotlight on the detention of thousands of women in Catholic workhouses, which were found to have extensive state involvement.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:credit: Julien Behal/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A former Magdalene Laundry in Dublin, one of several Catholic homes where thousands of young Irish women were sent.

item.title: I.H.T. Special: Social Media Firms Move to Capitalize on Popularity in Middle East
item.description: The rise of social media in the Arab world is changing the game for regional advertisers, pushing growth in digital advertising.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SARA HAMDAN
item.media:description: Egyptian protesters look at Facebook during a demonstration in Cairo on January 14.

item.title: I.H.T. Special: Haunted by War, Syrian Artists Put Raw Emotions on View
item.description: A Middle East-based gallery provides the region’s artists aid and a venue for expression.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NINA SIEGAL
item.media:description: "Freedom Graffiti' by the Syrian artist Tammam Hazzam.

item.title: United States Announces New Iran Sanctions
item.description: The United States blacklisted several organizations in Iran, widening the American effort to pressure the government over its nuclear program and human rights abuses.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Japan Spends Heavily to Keep Whaling Industry Afloat, Report Says
item.description: The report challenges assertions by the Japanese government that whaling is a tradition with wide support among Japanese consumers.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Bacteria Found Deep Under Antarctic Ice, Scientists Say
item.description: The discovery might advance knowledge of how life could survive on other planets, and it offers the first glimpse of a vast subglacial ecosystem of microscopic life.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GORMAN
item.media:credit: Dr. Alberto Behar, JPL/ASU; underwater camera funded by NSF and NASA
item.media:description: The first view of the bottom of subglacial Lake Whillans in Antarctica.

item.title: Clashes Erupt in Damascus; Prospects for Talks Dim
item.description: Some antigovernment activists described the fighting in Syria as part of a renewed effort by rebels to seize control of central Damascus, but that claim appeared to be exaggerated.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A building in the Damascus suburb of Zamalka was hit by a mortar shell fired by the Syrian Army on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: Feb.6
item.description: Student protests outside a Delhi college that hosted Gujarat Chief Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: 'Rigoletto' in Vegas, 'Manon Lescaut' in the Metro
item.description: Sometimes updating an opera's setting works; sometimes it doesn't.
item.dc:creator: By GEORGE LOOMIS
item.media:description: The new production of the Puccini opera "Manon Lescaut" at La Monnaie in Brussels.

item.title: 2 Azeri Opposition Leaders Are Charged With Inciting Riots
item.description: Opposition leaders in Azerbaijan said the arrests were politically motivated, and the United States Embassy in Baku, the capital, called for “transparency and fairness” in the investigation.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: TIMESCAST: Public Scrutiny of a Clandestine War
item.description: The confirmation hearing for C.I.A. director will highlight the nominee John O. Brennan’s role in overseeing drone strikes.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Best Asian Art? You Can Vote on It
item.description: What is Asian art, exactly? That depends on how you define Asia, as a contest based in Hong Kong demonstrates.
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU
item.media:description: "Wedding Memory" by Hassan Meer of Oman.

item.title: Raids in Britain, France and Belgium Focus on Smugglers of People
item.description: Immigration authorities went after people suspected of being members of gangs that smuggle people across or under the English Channel and into Britain.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL
